meanings.definition: The quality of being able to be sacrificed or disposed of
meanings.sent1: In the military, soldiers are trained to understand the expendability of equipment during combat.
meanings.sent2: The company viewed the old machinery's expendability as a cost-saving opportunity.
meanings.sent3: During the game of chess, the expendability of pawns often leads to strategic sacrifices.
meanings.sent4: To some, the expendability of certain fashion trends mirrors the fleeting nature of popularity.
meanings.sent5: The expendability of paper towels became evident when the cloth towels lasted much longer.

meanings.definition: The state of being considered easily replaceable or dispensable
meanings.sent1: In a competitive job market, employees may feel the pressure of expendability.
meanings.sent2: The temporary workers were aware of their expendability within the company.
meanings.sent3: The expendability of batteries in a remote control can be frustrating when they run out unexpectedly.
meanings.sent4: In the world of technology, the expendability of older models drives constant innovation.
meanings.sent5: The expendability of plastic utensils at a picnic highlights the convenience of disposable items.
